Poetry ought to study
What color needs to be next to which, or not,
such as blue with purple, and the purple with red,
and with red the orange-yellow,
then light yellow befriends green,
and green wants to be with blue.
And from ash-blue and yellow one mixes green.
right-middlePainters learn from the Rainbow which colors go together.

24. In the same manner, using certain rules,
those who go to work on damp plaster
prepare their tavolozze or boards,
and the Oil painters also use
the same arrangement on their palettes
white by one’s hand, then from each saturated color
is mixed two or three lighter tones.
These methods are ready and useful.
right-middleThose who work on damp plaster mix two or three lighter tones from each color, keeping the white next to the hand.

25. Indeed, the times Painters devote
to mixing colors will only be time gained;
there is no need to argue this point.
But to continue with Radiance,
such as moonlight, fire, lightning, candlelight, and forges:
one ought to judge, in each particular case,
how in lighting the surrounding area,
one always creates the same type of radiance.
right-middleMixing colors is never a waste of time, but is very beneficial.
right-middleOne must pay attention to colors and the appearances of all kinds of lights in order to distinguish among them.

26. The light of night–the Moon–shining
on houses and Churches, above and below,
will bestow a glimmer as pale as itself
on everything it touches.
Likewise the lightning, a harbinger
of violent thunder, chases the darkness
with a particularly blue fire
and furthermore, reveals its Reflection fleetingly.

27. We find, as we read in Pliny,
Art of Reflection also practiced in ancient times
by Antiphilus who, being an expert,
painted a youth blowing on a fire
with lively devotion to keep it burning;
and because of this blowing, the glow revealed
the interior of a very fine dwelling
as well as the flickering on the blower’s face, skillfully done.
right-middleExample of someone blowing on a fire, done by the ancient Painter Antiphilus.

28. Echion, whom we discuss elsewhere,
also wished to portray the Art of Reflection,
having revealed through the spreading of light,
a lovely young Bride going to bed,
following behind an older Matron:
to lighten the darkness,
she carries a fiery burning Torch
and proceeds with a modest bearing.
